Recent Dispatches

JANUARY 14, 2026
On the Ethics of Dressing a Reluctant Spatula

We were approached last month by a client in Osaka who wished to commission a bespoke evening gown for a spatula he described as "emotionally unavailable." During the initial consultation â€” a 20-minute pas de deux between Dr. Okafor-Strand and the client â€” it became clear that the spatula had not consented to the fitting.

This is a line we do not cross. At Maison du Objet, we believe firmly in object autonomy. We cannot, in good conscience, dress an object that does not wish to be dressed. The client was offered a full refund in the form of a contemporary dance piece valued at $2,400.

He accepted. He later described the dance as "devastating."

DECEMBER 3, 2025
Geoffrey Celebrates 14 Years of Service

On November 29th, we held a ceremony to honor Geoffrey's 14th year as Head of Client Relations. The event was attended by 200 guests, 47 objects, and one uninvited pigeon that we later offered a fitting to (it declined via aggressive cooing, which Dr. Okafor-Strand translated as "I am already perfectly dressed").

Geoffrey, as always, said nothing. He sat on a velvet cushion and held a small stack of papers with the same quiet dignity that has made him the most trusted name in inanimate client relations. His 97% satisfaction rating remains the highest of any employee, animate or otherwise.

When asked for comment, Geoffrey did not move. We took this as gratitude.

OCTOBER 19, 2025
Why We Danced Our Tax Return (And What the IRS Got Wrong)

Much has been made of our 2023 tax filing, which was submitted as a 45-minute choreographic work performed by Dr. Nina Okafor-Strand in the lobby of the IRS field office in Newark, New Jersey. We wish to clarify several points:

1. The pirouette in minute 12 clearly represents our Q3 operating expenses. The IRS's suggestion that it "could also be a grocery list" is frankly insulting.

2. The 8-minute floor sequence was our depreciation schedule. It was not, as one auditor suggested, "a cry for help."

3. We stand by the closing grand jetÃ© as an appropriate representation of net income. The fact that Dr. Okafor-Strand landed badly and sprained her ankle is, we maintain, an accurate reflection of our fiscal year.

âœ¦ Frequently Danced Questions

FDQ

We prefer the term "emotionally complex." Yes, all objects are welcome regardless of functional status. Some of our most successful fittings have been for objects that no longer serve their original purpose. A shattered vase in a Valentino gown is still a shattered vase â€” but it is a shattered vase that knows its worth.

We tried email from 2008 to 2011. The results were catastrophic. Written language lacks the nuance required to discuss the emotional needs of a corkscrew. In 2011, a misinterpreted email led to a client's butter knife being dressed in sportswear. The butter knife has never recovered. We moved to interpretive dance exclusively and have not looked back.

In 27 years of operation, this has happened exactly once. In 2016, a whisk rejected a silk charmeuse evening dress via what Madame Voss interpreted as "a shudder of contempt." The garment was redesigned as a deconstructed asymmetric drape, which the whisk accepted with what we believe was "begrudging respect." The fitting took nine additional months. We do not rush art.

Geoffrey is a 32mm Acco-brand binder clip, matte black, manufactured in Guangzhou in 2004. He holds a stack of approximately 15 pages at any given time. He has held these same pages since 2015. No one knows what is on the pages. We do not ask. His employee ID number is 0001, which predates several human employees. We do not question this either.

We do not "ship." Your object is escorted by a member of our Garment Transit Corps â€” a team of four individuals who have been trained in the art of carrying dressed objects with appropriate reverence. Transit fees start at $800 (domestic) and $4,200 (international). The escort will perform a brief departure dance at your doorstep. Tipping is not expected but a responsive jetÃ© is appreciated.

Weep openly in our foyer. This has a 100% success rate. We cannot explain why. The corkscrews seem to find it moving.
